meanings.def: the hard solid material that forms part of the surface of the earth and some other planets
examples: They drilled through several layers of rock to reach the oil.
a cave with striking rock formations (= shapes made naturally from rock)
The tunnel was blasted out of solid rock.
volcanic/igneous/sedimentary rocks
Ahead the vegetation broke into bare rock.
The castle is perched on a massive outcrop of rock.
The river runs between walls of sheer rock.
rocks that formed beneath the sea
an avalanche of loose rock

meanings.def: a mass of rock standing above the earth’s surface or in the sea
examples: the Rock of Gibraltar
The ship crashed into the infamous Sker Point rocks and broke into three pieces.
The ship hit some rocks and sank.
A great rock jutted out into the water.

meanings.def: a large single piece of rock
examples: They clambered over the rocks at the foot of the cliff.
The sign said ‘Danger: falling rocks’.
We made our way down into the river bed and stepped from rock to rock.
The path had been blocked by a rock fall.
The rocks were slippery as I tried to climb them.

meanings.def: a small stone
examples: Protesters pelted the soldiers with rocks.
Lars taught me to skip rocks.
They used to throw rocks at neighborhood dogs.
Demonstrators threw rocks at the police.

meanings.def: a type of loud popular music, developed in the 1960s, with a strong beat played on electric guitars and drums
examples: punk/indie/classic rock
a rock band/star/concert
a rock musician/song/album
I hate rap but I like rock.
Ryan changed the radio to a rock station.
She was a rock chick through and through.
influential rock critics
one of the biggest bands on the rock circuit

meanings.def: a type of hard sweet made in long sticks, often sold in places where people go on holiday by the sea
examples: a stick of Brighton rock

meanings.def: a precious stone, especially a diamond
a person who is emotionally strong and who you can rely on
examples: He is my rock.

meanings.def: in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant
to have an orgasm
to do something that you really enjoy
examples: He gets his rocks off listening to rap.

meanings.def: a relationship or business that is on the rocks is having difficulties and is likely to fail soon
examples: Sue's marriage is on the rocks.

meanings.def: served with pieces of ice but no water
examples: Scotch on the rocks

meanings.def: extremely steady and calm; that you can rely on

idioms.idiom: (caught/stuck) between a rock and a hard place
idioms.def: in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant

examples: He gets his rocks off listening to rap.

idioms.def: a relationship or business that is on the rocks is having difficulties and is likely to fail soon
examples: Sue's marriage is on the rocks.
Scotch on the rocks

idioms.def: extremely steady and calm; that you can rely on

meanings.def: to move gently backwards and forwards or from side to side; to make somebody/something move in this way
examples: (+ adv./prep.) The boat rocked from side to side in the waves.
She was rocking backwards and forwards in her seat.
rock somebody/something (+ adv./prep.) He rocked the baby gently in his arms.
The boat rocked slightly.
The raft was rocked by a huge wave.

meanings.def: to shock somebody/something very much or make them afraid
examples: The country was rocked by a series of political scandals.
The news rocked the world.

meanings.def: to shake or to make something shake violently
examples: The house rocked when the bomb exploded.
rock something The town was rocked by an earthquake.
(figurative) The scandal rocked the government (= made the situation difficult for it).

meanings.def: to dance to rock music
used to say that something is very good
examples: Her new movie rocks!

meanings.def: to wear something or have a style of clothing, hair, etc. that makes you look attractive or confident
examples: How to rock the retro look.
She rocked a red leather skirt at the award ceremony.

meanings.def: to do something that upsets a situation and causes problems
examples: She was told to keep her mouth shut and not rock the boat.

meanings.def: to cause people to question their basic beliefs about something
examples: an event that rocked the foundations of British politics
The scandal rocked the legal establishment to its foundations.

meanings.def: to cause people to question their basic beliefs about something
examples: This issue has shaken the foundations of French politics.
an event which rocked the foundations of British politics
The scandal rocked the legal establishment to its foundations.

idioms.def: to do something that upsets a situation and causes problems
examples: She was told to keep her mouth shut and not rock the boat.

idioms.idiom: rock/shake the foundations of something | rock/shake something to its foundations
idioms.def: to cause people to question their basic beliefs about something
examples: an event that rocked the foundations of British politics
The scandal rocked the legal establishment to its foundations.

idioms.idiom: shake/rock the foundations of something | shake/rock something to its foundations
idioms.def: to cause people to question their basic beliefs about something
examples: This issue has shaken the foundations of French politics.
an event which rocked the foundations of British politics
The scandal rocked the legal establishment to its foundations.
